translated: Description. Aścaryayogamālā also called Yogaratnāvalī or Yogaratnamālā The Rosary of Astonishing Yogas by Nāgārjuna with a short commentary called Lghuvṛtti by Guṇākara, a Jaina Śvetāmbara scholar. This Nāgārjuna is famous as the author or namesake of various works on magic ṣaṭkarman. A manuscript in the Asiatic Society in Bombay dates the composition of the work as CE. It was written. The text tells us to serve people's needs and delight them. It deals with standard matters of magic beginning with controlling others (vaśīkaraṇa). Then checking an enemy army (stambhana), killing enemies (śatrumāraṇa), attracting women (ākarṣaṇa), and ways of attaining various magical powers (siddhi).

translated: The Kauśikī, Vāgmatī, Gaṅgā, Gaṇḍakī, which arises from Dharma,🔽Śatyā, Abhadrā, and Alakanandā are not tainted by the faults of menstruation.

original: na duṣyate rajodoṣaiḥ sā nadī rudravaktra / //

translated: The rivers Vāgmatikā, Bhāratī, and Mānī are pure after three days, except during the rainy season.
